Title: (digital restoration) Beethoven Piano Concerto No.1 - Perahia/Solti, London 1987
Description:
I only listened to Perahia for his Mozart repertoire until i recently found out that he turned out to be a Beethoven-genius also. This piece in particular is one of Beethoven's initial attempts in the genre and has a lot of Mozart elements to it, making it pretty much suitable for Perahia as the number one Mozartean in my book alongside Andras Schiff (though i saw Schiff played Beethovens but weren't as impressive).
Under the baton of Sir Georg Solti, one the most sought-after conductor at the time, Perahia ft. LSO delivered what i recognize as the best rendition of the piece ever performed on stage. Oh and did i mention the solid 5 minutes-long 1st mvt cadenza?

Work title: Piano Concerto No. 1 in C major, Op. 15
Conductor: Sir Georg Solti
Soloist (Piano): Murray Perahia
Orchestra: London Symphony Orchestra
Venue: Barbican Centre, London, England
Record Date: March 1987
Restoration Date: Jun 2023

(00:00) I. Allegro con brio 
(12:46) cadenza
(17:49) II. Largo
(29:16) III. Rondo - Allegro Scherzando
(35:35) cadenza

--

Title: (digital restoration) Beethoven Symphony No. 5 - Sir Georg Solti, Tokyo 1990
Description:
This is probably the closest we've ever get to hear and see the perfect Fifth that is very reminiscent of Carlos Kleiber's century's recording 15 years prior. 
Sir Georg Solti is known to have researched the metronome setting in Beethoven's days and this is what we get to see as the result.
CSO have had their many different leadership over the years but in my opinion Solti's era was their all-time-highest. During which also that the orchestra had played outside of North America in its 80-year history.

Work title: Beethoven - Symphony No. 5 in C minor, Op. 67
Conductor: Sir Georg Solti
Orchestra: Chicago Symphony Orchestra (CSO)
Venue: Suntory Hall, Tokyo, Japan
Record Date: 15 Apr 1990
Restoration Date: 12 June 2023

(00:00) I. Allegro con brio
(07:49) II. Andante con moto
(17:30) III. Scherzo: Allegro
(22:33) IV. Allegro

--

Title: Chicago Symphony Mahler no. 5, Solti 1986
Description:
Georg Solti conducts the Chicago Symphony Orchestra in performance of Gustav Mahler’s Symphony no. 5 in C sharp minor on either March 19th or April 8th, 1986. The CSO archive lists two dates for Solti and Mahler no 5 broadcasts in1986. I thought maybe the April date was a repeat broadcast, but the length of performance for each date is different so I’m lead to believe it was both performed and broadcast twice. If anyone knows more info - please sure. 

There are a few videos on YouTube of Solti conducting the same symphony in Tokyo - but that was a week later on March 26th according to the CSO archive.

Note that this recording is also not the 1984/1985 record on Decca or London Records that was actually a performance recorded in 1970:
https://www.discogs.com/master/306891-Mahler-Solti-Chicago-Symphony-Orchestra-Symphony-No-5

Technical Info:
Scotch 209, quarter track stereo
10.5” reel
3 3/4 IPS

00:00 - Part I: Funeral march
12:46 - Part I: Moving stormily, with the greatest vehemence
27:24 - Part II: Scherzo
44:05 - Part III: Adagietto
54:01 - Part III: Rondo finale

Title: LIVE Broadcast (1982) : Cecile Licad performs Tchaikowsky Concerto No.1 conducted by Sir Georg Solti
Description:
In 1982 Cecile Licad at age twenty had her first engagement with the Chicago Symphony Orchestra under the baton of Sir Georg Solti -   which was broadcasted live on public television. At the beginning of this video, Sir Georg Solti was expressing his high esteem towards Cecile's great talent, knowing of her prodigious background as a young concert artist. It contained a short clip of their rehearsing the Tchaikowky Piano Concerto no.1 in B-flat minor, Op. 23 without the orchestra.  The outstanding cellist, Frank Miller, played the solo cello part of the second movement at this live performance.

It is note taking that many if not majority of great artists began their training with total dedication when they were very young, growing to develop a real discipline and love of music at a very  early age.  Their prodigious character is a product of hard work and study, love and dedication. This almost became their destiny that  propelled their professional life as with Cecile Licad,  who in 1981 was awarded the prestigious Leventritt Gold medal  into becoming a major concert artist of our days.  She joined the exclusive list of awardees through the years which included Van Cliburn, Gary Graffman,  Ityzak Perlman, and  Alexis Weissenberg, among others.

Title: Mussorgsky Pictures at an Exhibition CSO Solti
Description:
The complete performance of Pictures at an Exhibition given in the Royal Albert Hall as part of the BBC Promenade Concert series in 1981. Sitting next to the legendary Chicago Symphony Orchestra brass section I realised that nothing had prepared me for the huge, organic sound they made. I don't think any modern orchestra can or maybe chooses to make this sound now. Much of it is down to principal trumpet Herseth but I also remember the quality of the low end players providing the support for his fearless playing. It seems to have taken me a long time to get round to posting this so apologies to everyone for the long wait!

00:00 - Promenade
01:54 Gnomus
04:23 Promenade
05:28 The Old Castle
10:31 Promenade
11:05 Tuileries
12:12 Bydlo

Title: Siegfried Funeral Music - Götterdämmerung - Solti - VPO
Description:
Video showing Vienna Horns in F and Wagner Tuben, they are correctly called Wagner TUBEN (TUBE singular) (as in TUBES) and not TUBAS actually. Time and the need for a translation has changed that to tubas, just so you know (doubting Thomas's please look in the score).
This is here to lament the passing of a style of playing that is so rare to encounter these days - sheer uninhibited passionate unbridled and raw playing which has today been replaced by something more sterile and exact. I will blame conductors any day for wanting everything to sound the way a modern recording does. This is from the DECCA DVD "The Golden Ring" which is a Humphrey Burton documentary made during the recording of Götterdämmerung for the Solti Ring Cycle. Buy it from Amazon as well as the CDs with the definitive Siegfriedruf played by Roland Berger aged 21.

This is part of a collection of live "off air" recordings from radio broadcasts I have made since 1970, and I have recently preserved by transferring from tape to digital format. None of the recordings is derived from a commercial release, nor are they of commercial sound quality. No payment is sought for listening to these recordings, I am sharing them in the hope that they may give pleasure to other music lovers, as they have given pleasure to me. No copyright infringement is intended, please do contact me to allow me to correct the situation should this be the case.

Title: Stravinsky - Le Sacre du printemps - Georg Solti, Chicago Symphony
Stravinsky Rite of Spring Philadelphia Solti Feb 1964 Live
Description: Philadelphia and Rite of Spring were not frequently acquainted in the 1960s, as one commenter below observes. Stokowski’s commercial recording (from various takes jn sessions spread across 1929 and 1930) and Ormandy’s (from mono sessions in April and May of 1955) attest to the difficulty the players had in this repertoire, and EO’s own difficulties with its frequently shifting time signatures are recounted in the interviews I separately posted. Muti’s commercial recording by contrast only required two days in October of 1978. Here, Georg Solti guest conducts, one of two guest gigs he had with Philadelphia in the 1960s.

Title: Tippett,Tchaikovsky,Rossini - Chicago Symphony Orchestra - Sir Georg Solti (Royal Albert Hall, 1978)
Description:
0:00:00 Tippett Symphony No. 4
0:32:07 Tchaikovsky Symphony No. 6 'Pathétique'
1:20:13 Encore: Rossini Overture 'The Barber of Seville'

This BBC Promenade concert was given on 4 September 1978 in the Royal Albert Hall, London and marked not only the first UK concert performance of Tippett's 4th Symphony, but also the debut of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra at the Proms. They were of course conducted by Sir Georg Solti.

Chicago Symphony Orchestra
conducted by
Sir Georg Solti

For more details see: https://www.bbc.co.uk/events/e25q9r

This is part of a collection of live "off air" recordings from radio broadcasts I have made since 1970, and I have recently preserved by transferring from tape to digital format. Non of the recordings is derived from a commercial release, nor are they of commercial sound quality. No payment is sought for listening to these recordings, I am sharing them in the hope that they may give pleasure to other music lovers, as they have given pleasure to me. No copyright infringement is intended, please do contact me to allow me to correct the situation should this be the case.
